newsitem.title: POLAND: Poland launches EU-financed motorway construction.
newsitem.headline: Poland launches EU-financed motorway construction.

text.p: Polish Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz and European Transport Commissioner Neil Kinnock on Thursday opened construction of a 350-million Ecu motorway in Poland co-financed by the EU, PAP news agency said.

The 126-km motorway, between the southern cities of Wroclaw and Gliwice, will be part of an EU-assisted project to create a Trans-European West-East route linking the German city of Dresden and Lviv in Ukraine.
The European Union has awarded 68 million Ecus from its Phare aid progamme for the Polish motorway construction.
The European Investment Bank will provide 225 million Ecus and the Polish government will contribute the remainder, the Delegation of the European Union said in a statement.
"The investment will contribute to supporting European integration, by developing a modern transport network," it said.
Poland, an EU associate member, hopes for full membership around the year 2002 or earlier if possible.
The delegation said that under the first stage of the motorway construction launched on Thursday, more than 140 bridges will be modernised at a cost of nearly 38 million Ecus.
The bridge modernisation contract, the largest single contract signed under Phare since the programme started in 1989, has been awarded to Portuguese company Mota and Companhia, it said.
Under the Phare programme, the EU helps countries in central and eastern Europe, which toppled communism in 1989, to modernise their economies and infrastructure.
The Wroclaw-Gliwice motorway will also be part of Poland's $8 billion programme to build some 2,500 km of motorways within the next 15 years. -- Marcin Grajewski +48 22 653 9700
